Text/Description: Tip: leave at 1 for native one-contract P/L; set 0 to exclude without unchecking.
Upload and select files to enable optimization.

Objective controls what the optimiser is trying to maximise or minimise. 'Max Risk-Adjusted Return' (Sharpe) maximises (return - risk-free) per unit of risk, 'Min Risk' minimises portfolio risk, 'Max Return' maximises return, and 'Utility' minimises risk minus λ times expected return.

Return Model defines how returns are calculated. 'Arithmetic' computes returns as P_t / P_{t-1} - 1; 'Approximate log' uses ln(P_t) - ln(P_{t-1}); 'Exact log' uses exp(ln(P_t / P_{t-1})) - 1. The difference between approximate and exact log returns is very small for daily data but may accumulate over long horizons or large price changes.

Risk Measure determines how portfolio risk is computed. 'Variance' uses the covariance of returns. 'Semi-Variance' uses only returns below the mean. 'CVaR' (Conditional Value at Risk) estimates expected losses beyond a value-at-risk threshold. 'CDaR' (Conditional Drawdown at Risk) measures average drawdown beyond the VaR. 'EVaR' (Expected Value at Risk) is a more conservative tail measure.

Risk-Free Rate (annual %) sets the risk-free rate used for risk-adjusted objectives such as Sharpe. Typical values range from 0% to 5%. The optimiser converts this annual percentage to a daily decimal.
Risk Aversion λ is used when the Utility objective is selected. A lower λ emphasises return while a higher λ emphasises risk. Recommended values are between 1 and 5.
Confidence Level α specifies the percentile used for tail-based risk measures (CVaR, CDaR, EVaR). Typical values are 5% to 10%. A smaller α focuses on more extreme tail events.

Covariance Method controls how the covariance matrix is estimated. 'Sample' uses sample covariance; 'EWMA' uses an exponentially weighted moving average; 'Ledoit-Wolf' shrinks the sample covariance towards the identity matrix to reduce estimation error.

Weight Bounds specify the minimum and maximum allocation per asset. Use 0 to 1 for a long-only portfolio. Allowing a negative minimum permits short positions. Setting a maximum less than 1 encourages diversification.
Budget represents the sum of portfolio weights. A budget of 1 means the portfolio is fully invested. Values greater than 1 imply leverage; values less than 1 leave some capital uninvested.

Group Caps let you set an upper limit on the combined weight of specific symbols. Use the format 'AAPL,MSFT=0.5' to restrict the total weight of AAPL and MSFT to 50%. Separate multiple group caps with commas.
Strategy Caps let you limit the total allocation to a trading strategy. Enter values as 'trend=0.6, mean_reversion=0.4' to cap each strategy.
Turnover Cap sets an upper limit on portfolio turnover. This feature is reserved for future use and the input is disabled.

Text/Description: When reinvestment is enabled, compounded metrics will become the primary metrics used for performance calculations and display.
Past performance is not necessarily indicative of future results.
Returns are calculated on nominal account size (no reinvestment). For reinvestment returns, the compounded series is used.
Annual and drawdown percentages use the additive method (not reinvestment).
